newsitem.title: USA: Pulp mill contract debate divides Alaska town.
newsitem.headline: Pulp mill contract debate divides Alaska town.

text.p: The threat of a pulp mill closure has injected fierce emotion into the debate over a controversial long-term timber supply contract.

"Some people are getting real close to losing their livelihood that they've been at for 20 or 30 years and it probably causes them to do something they shouldn't," said Dick Coose, head of an advocacy group seeking to extend the contract held by Louisiana-Pacific subsidiary Ketchikan Pulp Co.

Coose, a retired government forester now heading Concerned Alaskans for Resources and Environment (CARE), said strong action is needed to reverse decades of logging restrictions in southeast Alaska's Tongass National Forest.
His organization has hired Chuck Cushman, a founder of the radical anti-environmental "Wise Use" movement, to galvanize local action.
"Compromise is probably not a word that we're thinking of right now, because we're the ones that have been compromising for the last 15 or 20 years," Coose said.

Just ask Jackie Canterbury, a Ketchikan ornithologist who works for an environmental advocacy group. Recently she had a pellet shot into her front window, a brush fire lit in her backyard and a series of harassing telephone calls.
"A lot of us have become almost like lepers," she said of her fellow environmentalists.
She attributes the increased hostility to Cushman's arrival in Ketchikan, a city on the southern tip of the southeast Alaska panhandle.
"When all of these things happen in a period of about six months, and it's never happened before, you can kind of correlate it," she said.
Ketchikan Pulp, which operates a large pulp mill in Ketchikan and saw mills in southeast Alaska, dominates the timber business in the Tongass, a rain forest comprising most of southeast Alaska.

The company says that unless Congress extends the company's 50-year Tongass timber supply contract by October, it will close the pulp mill. The contract is due to run out in 2004, but Ketchikan Pulp says it needs a 15-year extension to secure financing for needed environmental improvements at the aged mill.

If Ketchikan Pulp closes its pulp mill and local saw mill -- both fed with timber from the long-term contract -- the city will lose more than 1,200 jobs and $48 million in payroll, according to a study commissioned for the Ketchikan Gateway Borough.
